title.text: An Investigation of Deep Learning Systems for Suicide Risk Assessment

abstractContent.text: This work presents the systems explored as part of the CLPsych 2019 Shared Task.
More specifically, this work explores the promise of deep learning systems for suicide risk assessment .

introductionContent.text: In the United States alone, on average, approximately 1 person every 11 minutes kills themselves (.
In addition, the situation is worsened by the fact that 124 million Americans live in areas where there is a shortage of mental health providers (Bureau of Health Workforce, 2017).

Meta-studies have shown that the ability to predict suicide attempts has been near chance for decades, and researchers have argued for the necessity to dedicate research efforts to approaches based on machine learning (.
Machine learning systems which predict suicide risk have the potential to improve identification of people with heightened suicide risk.
This work is part of the 2019 CLPsych Shared Task 1, which focuses on predicting someone's degree of suicide risk using posts they have made on the public forum Reddit.

entities.text: predicting someone's degree of suicide risk

introductionContent.text: In this paper, we present our team's results from the Shared Task.
Specifically, in this work, we focused on two main objectives.
The first objective is the exploration of deep learning systems for this particular task.

Deep learning systems have demonstrated high performance in various NLP tasks, including text classification, however as is highlighted in past work (, have yet to outperform more shallow machine learning models, such as Support Vector Machines (SVM).
In this work, we focus on exploring various deep learning architectures, including convolutional neural networks, long shortterm memory networks, and neural network synthesis.
We find that deep learning models can outperform more traditional machine learning systems for suicide risk assessment.
In addition to exploring the promise of deep learning for risk assessment, we also present results for novelly tested features for this particular task.

datasetContent.text: This work leverages the data provided by the 2019 CLPsych Workshop organizers.
Our team's use of this data and participation in these tasks met the ethical review criteria discussed in.

The dataset includes a series of Reddit users who have posted on the r/SuicideWatch subreddit, with annotations from one of the following four categories: (a) No Risk, (b) Low Risk, (c) Moderate Risk, and (d) Severe Risk.
For any models performing within the scope of Task A, the dataset solely includes r/SuicideWatch posts.
The Task B dataset includes all of the r/SuicideWatch posts as well as each of the users' posts on any other subreddit.
The Task C dataset only looks at the non-SuicideWatch posts for these same users.
The dataset includes a post identifier, a user identifier, timestamp, subreddit name, title of the post, and body of the post.
